item.title: Zohran MamdaniÂàÜ‰∫´‰∫ÜÂò≤Á¨ëHannukahÂíå‚Äúcosplaying Jews‚ÄùÁöÑ‚ÄúÁóÖÊÄÅ‚ÄùËßÜÈ¢ëÔºåÂÄ°ÂØºÂõ¢‰ΩìÊåáÊéß | Zohran Mamdani shared ‚Äòsick‚Äô video mocking Hannukah and ‚Äòcosplaying Jews,‚Äô advocacy group charges
item.description:
A Jewish advocacy group slammed Democratic socialist mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani for posting a ‚Äúsick‚Äù video mocking Hannukah and ‚Äúcosplaying Jews.‚Äù

The mayoral front-runner shared a video on his X account last year from the Geeta Brothers Duet Group, showing two men wearing wigs dancing behind a menorah, playing with dreidels and celebrating with Punjabi-style music.

‚ÄúZohran Mamdani posts Indian men cosplaying Jews, spinning dreidels and lighting the menorah,‚Äù pro-Jewish group Stop Antisemitism wrote in a post to X Saturday, which included the controversial song.

‚ÄúOur holidays and traditions are sacred and not for your comedic pleasure _ZohranKMamdani ‚Äî this is sick.‚Äù

Mamdani, 33, shared the campy song called ‚ÄúHey Hannukah‚Äù during last year‚Äôs Festival of Lights.

‚ÄúHappy 3rd night of Hanukkah from Astoria and Long Island City,‚Äù the Queens lawmaker wrote on X at the time.

The video is from the 2015 parody album ‚ÄúPunjabi Christmas Album Hits‚Äù from the Geeta Brothers ‚Äî a side project of Sikh-Canadian musician and comedian Jus Reign.

Mamdani shared a similar video from the same comedy group on Christmas Eve 2024.

‚ÄúWishing you all a very merry Christmas from Astoria and Long Island City,‚Äù the self-described ‚Äúnepo-baby‚Äù wrote, sharing a video for the song ‚ÄúJingle Bells,‚Äù in which the performers wear similar wigs.

The tone-deaf post is not the only reason Jewish New Yorkers are outraged over the rise of the socialist pol.

Some Big Apple voters were gobsmacked when they received pro-Mamdani text messages that invoked the horrors of the October 7th attack in Israel.

‚ÄúMy friend Idan was murdered on October 7 at the Re‚Äôim music festival. The war is personal to me, as it is to many in our community,‚Äù a text shared with The Post read.

‚ÄúThe war is personal to me, as it is to many others in our community. Idan believed in peace, just like Zohran does,‚Äù the text read. It‚Äôs unclear who sent them.

The state assemblyman has previously come under fire for refusing to recognize Israel‚Äôs right to exist as a Jewish state.

Earlier this week, the Bronx Science graduate, who was born in Uganda to Indian parents, alienated Black New Yorkers when it was revealed that he claimed he was African American on his application to Columbia University.
item.author: Shane Galvin

item.title: Âè¶‰∏ÄÂè™È≤®È±ºÂú®Ë∑ùÁ¶ªÊ∏∏Ê≥≥ËÄÖ100Ëã±Â∞∫ËøúÁöÑÊ¥õÂÖãÂ®ÅÊµ∑Êª©Ë¢´ÂèëÁé∞ÔºåÂØºËá¥ÂÖ≥Èó≠ | Another shark spotted 100 feet away from swimmers at Rockaway Beach, prompting closure
item.description:
It‚Äôs ‚ÄúShark Weekend‚Äù in New York City.

Another shark was spotted swimming precariously close to swimmers at Rockaway Beach Saturday ‚Äî just 100 feet away ‚Äî prompting the closure of the popular watering hole for the second day in a row.

NYPD drones captured the toothsome predator around 6 p.m. in the area of Beach 113th and Beach 115th streets in Rockaway Park, Queens ‚Äî with video showing the shark writhing just beneath the surface of the water, shockingly close to oblivious swimmers.

The shark‚Äôs fin seemed to sneak above the surface of the water for just a moment before it disappeared back into the Atlantic‚Äôs murky depths.

‚ÄúThe shark was last seen swimming back into open waters,‚Äù the city‚Äôs Deputy Mayor for Public Safety Kaz Daughtry tweeted.

‚ÄúFrom the sky to the surf, we are constantly patrolling with drones to detect both shark activity and distressed swimmers. This is how we stay ahead of danger ‚Äî and keep New Yorkers safe.‚Äù

Saturday‚Äôs sighting, the fourth in two days, shuttered the shore from Beach 92nd to Beach 124th streets.

Big Apple shores are apparently drawing more than just tourists and sun-seekers this summer.

On July 4, there were three shark sightings off the coast of Rockaway Park ‚Äî at Beach 32nd Street, another at Beach 144th Street and a third at Beach 30th Street.¬†

‚ÄúThese sightings were very close to beachgoers,‚Äù Daughtry warned in a post to X on Friday.

Officials have not said which type of sharks were spotted. However, species like Atlantic Menhaden and smooth dogfish have been known to favor New York waters.

In a statement Thursday, Gov. Kathy Hochul said New York park officials are utilizing drones and helicopters to beef up shark patrols in an effort to prevent any man-eater encounters.

‚ÄúWe are continuing to strengthen our shark surveillance capabilities and safety tactics at these beaches to help protect these treasured summertime traditions,‚Äù Hochul wrote.

‚ÄúI encourage all beachgoers to stay safe, stay alert, and always follow the direction of lifeguards and park staff,‚Äù the governor advised.
item.author: Shane Galvin

item.title: Âú®ÂØªÊâæ‰∏éÂ¶ªÂ≠êÂú®ÁâπÂÖãÊñØÂíåÂáØÁßëÊñØÁæ§Â≤õÊóÖË°å‰∏≠Â§±Ë∏™ÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶‰∫∫Â∏ÉËé±ÊÅ©¬∑Â°î‰º¶ÊñØÔºà Brian Tarrence ÔºâÊó∂ÂèëÁé∞ÁöÑÂ∞∏‰Ωì | Body found in search for Brian Tarrence, the New Yorker who went missing on trip with wife in Turks and Caicos
item.description:
A man‚Äôs decomposed body has turned up in the search for a New York man who mysteriously went missing last week in Turks and Caicos, local authorities said.

Investigators found ‚Äúthe body of a deceased male in a decomposed state‚Äù during a search in the area of Grace Bay ‚Äî but have not said whether it belongs to Brian Tarrence, who went missing June 25, CBS reported, citing the Royal Turks and Caicos Islands Police Force.

Tarrence, 51, who lived in Manhattan, was last seen three days after arriving at the lush Caribbean island for a romantic anniversary getaway with his wife of a year. He was caught on security video leaving his Airbnb at Paradise Inn in Grace Bay, Providenciales, around 3:30 a.m.

His wife, who remains in Turks and Caicos, has hired a private investigator to abet the search.

Tarrence, the vice president of Diligent Software, had his cellphone and wallet when he left his rental and was in an area known to be safe, that private investigator claimed.

‚ÄúSo far, we haven‚Äôt been successful in anything, but we‚Äôre not giving up hope,‚Äù private investigator Carl DeFazio, a former NYPD cop and US Marine, told Fox News last week.

DeFazio stated that he is trying to obtain records of Tarrence‚Äôs phone activity while on the island in an attempt to piece together his movements and potentially find him alive.

The US State Department issued a travel advisory in March for tourists visiting the popular vacation island chain ‚Äî with violent robberies rising by 143% and gun-related crimes up 123% in the year 2024, according to InSight Crime.

Investigators have stated that no criminality is yet suspected in Tarrence‚Äôs disappearance.
item.author: Shane Galvin

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇËøéÈù¢ËÄåÊù•ÁöÑBelt ParkwayËΩ¶ÊµÅÈÄ†Êàê6‰∫∫Âèó‰º§ | Six injured when car barrels into oncoming Belt Parkway traffic in NYC
item.description:
Six people were injured ‚Äì two critically ‚Äì in a fiery crash in Queens when a BMW struck a highway medium and vaulted over the barrier, striking two vehicles in oncoming traffic, cops said.

The 24-year-old driver of the white 2015 BMW was headed east on the Belt Parkway at Exit 17 near Cross Bay Boulevard when he lost control, hit the concrete barrier and launched over it around 6 a.m. Saturday, police said.

The BMW then smacked into a 2016 Honda CRV and a red 2022 Hyundai ‚Äî shearing its roof off, dramatic photos from the scene show ‚Äî before catching fire, authorities said.¬†

The driver of the BMW and a female passenger were rushed to Brookdale Hospital in critical condition, a police spokesman said. The female‚Äôs age was unknown, according to cops.

A 34-year-old woman who was driving the Hyundai was also taken to the hospital in stable condition, cops said.

The white BMW‚Äôs hood appears to have been peeled back from the impact.

Photos showed victims being rushed to an ambulance, while others were treated by emergency responders at the scene.

A 21-year-old woman and two 25-year-old men in the BMW were taken to a hospital in stable condition, cops said.

It was unclear what caused the driver to lose control but police said speed may have been an issue.

One photogrph shows a baby seat at the scene, but police said they had no information about minors being injured in the crash.

The NYPD‚Äôs Collision Investigation Squad was probing the wreck, cops said.
item.author: Tina Moore

item.title: Ë≠¶ÂØüËØ¥Ôºå‰∏ÄÂêçÂ¶áÂ•≥Âú®Â∏ÉÊúóÂÖãÊñØÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Ë≠¶ÂØüÂ±ÄÊãòÁïôÊúüÈó¥Ê≠ª‰∫° | Woman dies while in NYPD custody in the Bronx, cops said
item.description:
A young woman died in NYPD custody at a Bronx precinct station house Saturday after police officers‚Äô attempts to revive her failed, cops said.

The 18-year-old became unconscious while in custody at the 41 Precinct station on Longwood Ave. in Hunts Point around 12:30 a.m., cops said.

Police called for an ambulance and attempted to revive her, officials said.

‚ÄúMultiple officers performed CPR while awaiting EMS response,‚Äù cops said in an official release about the woman‚Äôs death.

EMS rushed the woman to Lincoln Hospital, but she couldn‚Äôt be saved, police said.

Her identity wasn‚Äôt immediately released.

Police declined to say why the woman was in custody and cited an ongoing invesigation being done by the NYPD‚Äôs Force Invesigation Division.
item.author: Tina Moore

item.title: ‰ªé8000Ëã±Â∞∫È´òÁ©∫ÊãçÊëÑÊ¢ÖË•øÁôæË¥ß7Êúà4Êó•ÁÉüËä±Ë°®ÊºîÁöÑËà™ÊãçÁÖßÁâá | Aerial photographs of Macy‚Äôs 4th of July Fireworks show taken from an altitude of up to 8,000 feet
item.description:
Let freedom fly!

A photographer who doubles as a pilot was the highest in the Manhattan sky on July 4th ‚Äî and The Post obtained his breathtaking aerial photographs of the 49th Annual Macy‚Äôs 4th of July Fireworks show taken from a staggering altitude of 7,500 to 8,000 feet.

Filip Wolak captured the stunning spectacle ‚Äî as 80,000 shells launched from four barges on the East River ‚Äî from above the controlled airspace, which is at 7,000 feet.

‚ÄúWhat makes it special was I was the only guy out there. I got the best seat,‚Äù Wolak, a native of Poland, told The Post Saturday.

The astounding images reveal the brightly colored plumes of pyrotechnics forth from the river, surrounded by the panorama of the city.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve always been fascinated by the fireworks and of course, they‚Äôre the best here. And I don‚Äôt necessarily like crowds, so I find a way of watching from that point of view.‚Äù

While fireworks themselves are ‚Äúquite challenging to photograph,‚Äù especially while flying a plane, he does have someone seated beside him to watch for traffic and altitude, he said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a high level of stress, but it‚Äôs a good stress,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúAnd when I take photographs from the sky, I slow down the airplane to the minimum flyable speed which allows me to capture images that are not blurry.‚Äù

Wolak snaps the Independence Day pyrotechnics every year, but thought he wouldn‚Äôt be able to this time around because airspace in the tristate area had been closed at 10:30 p.m. when President Trump visited the area.

‚ÄúI thought there was a chance I would not make it because the president came to town last night and they basically shut down the whole airspace,‚Äù he said.
item.author: Angela Barbuti

item.title: Êï∞ÁôæÂêçË¢´ÊåáÊéßÁöÑÊùÄ‰∫∫ÁäØ„ÄÅÂ∞èÂÅ∑ÂíåÊÄßÁäØÁΩ™ËÄÖÔºåÂåÖÊã¨ÈùûÊ≥ïÁßªÊ∞ëÔºåÂú®ÂπøÊ≥õÁöÑËÅîÈÇ¶Ë°åÂä®‰∏≠Ë¢´ÊäìËé∑ | Hundreds of accused murderers, thieves and sex offenders, including illegal migrants, nabbed in sweeping federal operation
item.description:
They brought the hammer down on the worst of the worst.

Federal authorities have swept up 264 wanted criminals ‚Äî including two illegal migrants wanted for sex crimes ‚Äî in New Jersey in an ongoing mission dubbed ‚ÄúOperation Apex Hammer‚Äù that nabbed suspects wanted for murder, robbery and sexual offenses, including those against children.

Those arrested include 17 homicide suspects, 95 gang members, including several others wanted for serious violent and sexual offenses, federal officials said.

U.S. Marshal Juan Mattos Jr. and Acting U.S. Attorney Alina Habba called the collaboration among federal, state, and local law enforcement ‚Äúa major success in combating violent crime and restoring public safety.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe are doing multiple cases at once to make sure that we clean up as quickly as possible,‚Äù Habba told Fox News of the operation in June. ‚ÄúViolent crime is number one. It is very clear from this administration. That is all we‚Äôre focused on.‚Äù

At least two of the suspects were illegal immigrants, police sources said.¬†

The suspects had 2,625 prior arrests among them, or about 10 each, officials said.

Illegal Guatemalan immigrant Lorenzo Benitez, 54, was arrested on June 4 in Plainfield, N.J., and faces multiple counts of sexual assault in Keansburg, N.J., law enforcement officials said.

Darlin Franco-Guzman, 25, an illegal immigrant from Honduras, was wanted in Baltimore County, MD, for burglary and attempted sexual assault of a 12-year-old girl, and was arrested on June 10th in Trenton, the officials said.

The other fugitives‚Äô crimes ranged from kidnapping and sex assault to a drive-by shooting murder.

Stephen Bullock, 32, was arrested on June 13 on charges that he allegedly kidnapped and sexually assaulting a 76-year-old woman in Camden County. Shawn Davis, 38, was arrested in Brooklyn for a 2024 homicide in Trenton, according to officials.

Luis Duval-Jimenez, 31, was being sought for allgedly running over a police officer in South Brunswick in May. Trasuf Bennett, 20, and an unidentified juvenile accomplice were arrested on June 19 for the drive-by shooting murder of a 20-year-old man in Milleville, N.J., officials said.

Francisco Ruiz, 67, was wanted for sexual assault by contact, terroristic threats, endangering the welfre of a child and criminal restraint, officials said. He was arrested on June 20 in Bayonne.

Officers also seized 14 illegal firearms during the operation.

Additional reporting by Tina Moore
item.author: Joe Marino

item.title: ËøôÁßçÊ∞¥ÊûúÊØèÊµÅË°å130ÁæéÂÖÉ‚ÄîÂéüÂõ†Â¶Ç‰∏ã | This fruit costs $130 a pop ‚Äî here‚Äôs why
item.description:
Look at those melons!

Japanese crown melons are known throughout the agricultural world as ‚Äúthe king of fruits,‚Äù and Asian supermarket HMart‚Äôs Upper West Side location is running a special on them: $130 apiece, marked down from $160.

Hurry, because on Thursday the store at 210 Amsterdam Ave. had just four left.

The muskmelons ‚Äî otherwise known as the Shizuoka crown melon, as its grown in the western part of the Shizuoka prefecture ‚Äî come packaged in a sleek, black gift box with gold lettering. Inside the supermarket, they‚Äôre kept in lucite.

The big-money melons are renowned for their unparalleled sweetness, subtle flavor and silky texture. Fans of the rare fruit claim the Japanese crown practically melts in your mouth.

It‚Äôs some of the priciest produce in the Big Apple.

Each crown boasts a T-shaped stem, which verifies the melon‚Äôs ‚Äúone tree, one fruit‚Äù growing method. One melon is allowed to grow on the vine, concentrating all of the plant‚Äôs nutrients into a single fruit.

They also require almost constant attention. The temperature, the humidity in the air, the amount the melon‚Äôs watered ‚Äî all are exacting.

Before they can receive the crown seal of approval, each and every melon must pass specific flavor, sugar content, appearance, and ripeness standards.

A good source of potassium and vitamins A and C, the luxury fruit begins to ripen once its harvested, and should be kept at room temperature until snack time. And even then, you need to refrigerate the melon for 2 to 3 hours before consuming.

On average, the pale green melons weigh 3.3 pounds, and are larger than a bocce ball, but smaller than a bowling ball.

Butterfield Market on Lexington Ave between 77th and 78th streets usually carries the melons, but are presently sold out. The store is due to receive a fresh delivery this month.

The market sells 36 melons a week, when in stock, manager Ken Williams told The Post.

‚ÄúPaying that much for fruit is a bold decision,‚Äù said Dr. Loulia Gourari, 35, who stopped to take a look at HMart‚Äôs crown melons this week. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a nice gift for someone who has everything.‚Äù

The melon is also served at J≈çji NY, a sushi restaurant in One Vanderbilt.

The HMart price is a bargain compared to some of the websites that‚Äôll deliver the penultimate fruit to your door.

They can be ordered online through Ikigai Fruits (each priced at $177 ‚Äî ‚Äúwith delivery‚Äù) and are available for pre-order (with next day delivery) through Melissa‚Äôs Produce, which charges $159 without delivery.
item.author: Chris Harris, Helayne Seidman

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Ë≠¶ÂØüÂú®ÂìàËé±ÂßÜÂå∫Â∫ÜÁ•ùÁã¨Á´ãÊó•Êó∂Ë¢´ÁÉüËä±Âáª‰∏≠ÁúºÁùõ | NYPD cop struck in eye by firework during Independence Day celebration in Harlem
item.description:
A police officer was struck in the face with a firework while trying to control a large crowd in Harlem during July 4 celebrations, cops said.

The cop was at 125th Street and Lenox Avenue around 1:15 a.m. when he was hit in the left eyebrow with the firework, police said.

It‚Äôs unclear if the incident was accidental or if someone aimed at the officer, authorities said.

‚ÄúNo one was arrested,‚Äù the source said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs pretty much up in the air right now.‚Äù¬†

The officer, who was on duty, was taken to Harlem Hospital in stable condition.
item.author: Tina Moore

item.title: 68Â≤ÅÁöÑNJÁî∑Â≠êÂõ†CybertruckÁ∫≥Á≤πÁ∫≥Á≤πÁ†¥ÂùèË°å‰∏∫Ëá™È¶ñ | NJ man, 68, turns self in over Cybertruck swastika vandalism
item.description:
This dentist sure has a dirty mouth.

Elmo Randolph, 68, turned himself into police in the upscale Bergen County borough of Closter on Thursday after being caught scribbling a swastika on a parked car.

Randolph, of Orange, was charged with fourth-degree bias intimidation, according to the Daily Voice, which shared video footage of the alleged crime.

In the footage, captured by one of the car‚Äôs many cameras, a baseball cap-donning Randolph is seen in his car on June 15, parked next to a Tesla Cybertruck outside Gary‚Äôs Liquors in the Closter Plaza.

He then opens his car door, leans out, and, with his fingers, scrawls a swastika onto the side of the dirty vehicle, the video shows.

The Cybertruck‚Äôs owner reported the vandalism on June 16, and shared the car‚Äôs surveillance footage with cops, the outlet reported.

Randolph was identified from the video, and turned himself in after learning the Closter Detective Bureau was looking for him.

In 2001, he was one of the plaintiffs in an American Civil Liberties Union lawsuit filed against the New Jersey State Police.

Randolph claimed he‚Äôd been stopped by police approximately 100 times, but never received a ticket.

He also alleged that he was subjected to searches of his car and interrogations about his profession, as well as how and where he obtained his luxury car.

Randolph received $75,000 from the state thanks to a 2002 settlement.

Randolph could not be reached for comment Saturday.
item.author: Chris Harris

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇËÆ°ÂàíÂú®ÁπÅÂøôÁöÑÁöáÂêéÂå∫Ëµ∞Âªä‰∏äÂª∫ÈÄ†Ëá™Ë°åËΩ¶ÈÅìÊòØ‚ÄúÁÅæÈöæÁöÑÁßòËØÄ‚Äù ÔºöÊâπËØÑËÄÖ | NYC plan to create bike lanes along busy Queens corridor is ‚Äòrecipe for disaster:‚Äô critics
item.description:
Queens residents and business owners are fighting a city plan to plop bike lanes onto 31st Street in Astoria, calling it a ‚Äúrecipe for disaster‚Äù that will crush commerce and threaten safety.¬†

The city Department of Transportation is proposing to narrow parking lanes from 13 to 8 feet and traffic lanes from 14 feet to 11, and move the parking lanes away from the curb, to make way for bike paths between 36th and Newton avenues.

While the proposal has the full-throated support of car-hating, socialist lawmakers like Councilwoman Tiffany Cab√°n, Assemblywoman Jessica Gonz√°lez-Rojas and state Sen. Kristen Gonzalez, merchants told The Post the blueprint would make it nearly impossible for trucks to reach businesses.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be forced to shut down because we will not be able to load and unload the materials and products,‚Äù said Panos Adamopoulos, who owns Pilates Designs, a pilates equipment manufacturer on 31st Street since 1984, with his wife Sylvia Fuster.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs asphyxiation,‚Äù he said, adding that his 16 employees‚Äô jobs are on the line.¬†

Even if a driver finds a parking space ‚Äì not easy with steel columns of the overhead N/W subway line in the way ‚Äî they‚Äôd have to cross an eight-foot bike lane and a three-foot buffer zone to get to the sidewalk.¬†

King Souvlaki, a food truck operating at 31st Street and 31st Avenue since 1979, would be forced to hit the road.¬†

‚ÄúThere would be no other space on that intersection for us,‚Äù said owner Lampros Tsampas.¬†

‚ÄúSome people have said, ‚ÄòYou can just park in the floating parking area and serve into the bike lane,‚Äô but that‚Äôs not safe at all,‚Äù he said.

The DOT said the redesign aims to improve safety, as 126 vehicle occupants, 33 pedestrians and 24 bikers were injured ‚Äî and two vehicle occupants killed ‚Äî along the mile-long stretch between 2020 and 2024 ‚Äî making it ‚Äúone of the most dangerous streets in Queens,‚Äù according to a department spokesperson.

Astoria native Joseph Mirabella said the new road configuration would be a nightmare for his 90-year-old amputee grandmother.¬†

‚ÄúGetting her in and out of the car and her wheelchair and having her cross these bike lanes is a huge safety concern,‚Äù said Mirabella, 25.¬† ‚ÄúThe DOT is calling this a safety and accessibility improvement plan ‚Äì and that‚Äôs preposterous.‚Äù

The proposed bicycle lanes would also interfere with the current pick-up and drop-off zones for pre-school- to high school-aged students enrolled in St. Demetrios School near 31st Street and 30th Avenue.¬†

The school was among 50 businesses and institutions that signed onto a June 3 letter to DOT Commissioner Ydanis Rodr√≠guez begging him to reconsider the scheme ‚Äî which could be implemented as soon as this summer.

‚ÄúMultiple instances of children being struck by heedless bicycle traffic have been documented across the city . . . until this problem is adequately addressed citywide, we cannot be expected to absorb the consequences,‚Äù reads one section of the seven-page letter.¬†

As of Friday, more than 4,200 people have signed onto a Change.org petition against the proposal ‚Äì which also cited increased traffic congestion, pollution and delayed 911 responses as concerns.¬†

The roadway is an ‚Äúindustrial conduit‚Äù that connects the Robert F. Kennedy Bridge to the 59th Street Bridge to the Midtown tunnel, noted Nancy Esposito, whose family owns Brothers Supply Corp., an HVAC company on 35th Avenue and 31st Street.¬†

‚ÄúThis would have an unbelievable ripple effect,‚Äù said Esposito. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre very, very concerned for the safety of our community and the wellbeing of our companies because of this plan.‚Äù

A DOT spokesperson said that redesigns like this one ‚Äúsuccessfully improve safety and support local businesses while keeping traffic moving.‚Äù The department has met with dozens of business owners on 31st Street ‚Äúto adjust our proposal based on their feedback,‚Äù they added.
item.author: Georgia Worrell

item.title: ÊùÄÊâãËßÜÂõæÔºöÂ•≥ÊºîÂëòÂú®Â£∞Áß∞620‰∏áÁæéÂÖÉÁöÑÂû´Â≠ê‰∏äÁöÑËêΩÂú∞Á™óÂêéËæìÊéâ‰∫ÜÊ≥ïÂæãÊñó‰∫âÔºå‰ΩøÂ•πÊö¥Èú≤Âú®‚ÄúËá¥ÂëΩÁöÑÁ¥´Â§ñÁ∫øÊµ¥‚Äù‰∏≠ÔºåËÑ∏‰∏äÁïô‰∏ã‰∫ÜÁóÖÂèò | Killer view: Actress loses legal battle after claiming floor-to-ceiling windows in $6.2M pad exposed her to ‚Äòlethal UV bath‚Äô that left lesions on her face
item.description:
A Murray Hill actress who claimed her killer view of the East River exposed her to a ‚Äúpotentially lethal UV bath‚Äù has lost her legal battle with the building‚Äôs owners and developers.

A Manhattan judge dismissed a $1 million lawsuit from Jennifer Betit Yen, a skin cancer survivor who sued after developing lesions on her face from the floor-ceiling-windows in her luxe, $6.2 million First Avenue pad, asserting Yen had not proven her claims of negligence.

Reps for developer Soloviev Building Co. and the building‚Äôs board of managers repeatedly told Yen, 48, and her film producer husband J. Peyton Worley, 47, the unit ‚Äúhad 100% UV protection,‚Äù the couple alleged in their Manhattan Supreme Court lawsuit.

But the couple signed a purchase agreement in which they agreed not to rely on ‚Äúany selling brochures, advertisements, websites, representations, warranties, statements or estimates of any nature whatsoever‚Äù when they bought the unit in the 43-story skyscraper near East 40th Street, the developer successfully argued.

The June 27 dismissal of Yen‚Äôs case was ‚Äúwith prejudice,‚Äù a legal term meaning she cannot bring the claims again, attorneys Alex Estis and Norman Flitt said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre very appreciative and thankful that the judge saw it for what it was, which was a meritless lawsuit and dismissed it as such,‚Äù Estis said.¬†

Yen, who hosts the series ‚ÄúFilm Lab Presents‚Äù and has had roles in ‚ÄúRoyal Pains‚Äù and other TV shows, said she repeatedly questioned the building‚Äôs reps about whether the home had protection from ultra violet radiation, especially because she had previously battled melanoma.

‚ÄúI am in this surreal situation where I unknowingly basically sat in a potentially lethal UV bath almost every day, during peak sun hours, thinking I was safe,‚Äù she wrote¬†in a blog post¬†last year.

A lawyer for Yen and Worley didn‚Äôt respond to a message seeking comment.

The couple snagged the swanky¬†2,984-square-foot¬†four bedroom, 4.5 bath home in November 2021 ‚Äî where ‚Äúevery single external wall is floor to ceiling glass window,‚Äù according to their lawsuit.
item.author: Kathianne Boniello

item.title: ÁñØÁãÇÁöÑÂ±ïÊúõÂÖ¨Âõ≠‚ÄúÁãóÊùÄÊâã‚ÄùÂõûÂà∞‰ªñÁöÑÊóßÊñπÂºèÔºåÂ®ÅËÉÅË¶ÅÂ∞ÑÊùÄÂÆ†Áâ©‰∏ª‰∫∫ | Crazed Prospect Park ‚Äòdog killer‚Äô back to his old ways, threatens to shoot pet owner
item.description:
He‚Äôs one of man‚Äôs best friend‚Äôs worst enemies.

The crazed, stick-toting Brooklyn vagrant who infamously killed a golden retriever named Moose in Prospect Park three years ago is back to ‚Äúterrorizing‚Äù both human and beast alike, victims told The Post.

Moose‚Äôs owner, Jessica Chrustic, revealed this week that her dog‚Äôs maniacal murderer ‚Äúthreatened to shoot me with a gun‚Äù on April 23 outside the Picnic House in the park.

‚ÄúI filed a police report, and still, nothing‚Äôs been done,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThis man is allowed to exist in this public space and continue to threaten people.‚Äù

The unhinged hobo lunged at another woman‚Äôs dog last weekend near Grand Army Plaza.

‚ÄúI was really caught off guard because it was just so startling,‚Äù said the latest victim who asked to remain anonymous and described the man as ‚Äúextraordinarily aggressive.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was just walking along with my dog, and he sort of emerged from out of nowhere,‚Äù the still-shaken pooch owner recalled . ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt want to turn around and maybe give him a reason to say something to me, so I kept going.‚Äù

Then, as the woman and her pooch ‚Äî a 6-year-old miniature schnauzer ‚Äî crossed his path, ‚Äúthis a‚Äìhole made a move towards my dog ‚Äî basically lunging at him, as if he was going to hit my dog.

‚ÄúHe started saying something to me about my dog, but I didn‚Äôt understand what he was saying ‚Äìand wasn‚Äôt sticking around to find out.‚Äù

She pulled the pooch closer to her, picked up the pace, and left the park.

‚ÄúSomeone like that shouldn‚Äôt be out in public, threatening or trying to intimidate people,‚Äù she said.

The dreadlocked creep still totes a terrifying 5-foot-long stick, which Chrustic has said he used to pummel tragic 2-and-a-half-year-old Moose to death on Aug. 3, 2002, she said. He was never arrested or charged in the incident.

After Moose‚Äôs killing, Chrustic told The Post she was distressed by the NYPD‚Äôs ‚Äúdisinterest‚Äù in the case. She also chided local Councilmember Shahana Hanif for ‚Äúexpressing her greatest concern for the well-being of the attacker and not the man‚Äôs victims.‚Äù

Hanif did not respond to requests for comment.

‚ÄúThere is one man in a park who is consistently terrorizing that space, threatening people,‚Äù Chrustic said, adding she‚Äôs reminded of the pain of that terrible day three years ago whenever she sees him wandering around the famed greenspace.

Chrustic has spotted the man a handful of times this year.

‚ÄúMy personal understanding is [the police] don‚Äôt want to deal with mentally ill people,‚Äù Chrustic said. ‚ÄúIf there was a mentally ill person pushing people onto the subway tracks, something would‚Äôve been done by now.‚Äù

The NYPD and Parks Department did not return messages seeking comment.
item.author: Chris Harris

item.title: ‚ÄúNEPO BABY‚Äù Zohran MamdaniÂ£∞Áß∞ÔºåÂ∞ΩÁÆ°‰ªñÁöÑËñ™Ê∞¥ÂíåÁâπÊùÉÊàêÈïøÁªèÂéÜÔºå‰ΩÜ‰ªñÂú®Èì∂Ë°åÁöÑÂ≠òÊ¨æÂ∞ë‰∫é2000ÁæéÂÖÉ | ‚ÄòNepo baby‚Äô Zohran Mamdani claims to have less then $2K in the bank ‚Äî despite his salary and privileged upbringing
item.description:
Self-described ‚Äúnepo baby‚Äù Zohran Mamdani declared a measly $2,000 in the bank on his latest state disclosures.

That‚Äôs despite his privileged upbringing and family money ‚Äî and an annual salary of $131,000 as a state lawmaker, a job he‚Äôs had for five years.

The 33-year-old socialist Democratic nominee for NYC mayor did list one unusual asset ‚Äî four acres of land in his native Uganda that he acquired about a decade ago, worth between $150,000 and $250,000.

He disclosed no US property or investments on the documents, released by the state this week.

The $2,000 on his form comes from a retirement plan from the housing-focused social-justice organization Chhaya, where he worked briefly as a ‚Äúforeclosure prevention counselor‚Äù in 2019, before he was elected in 2020 to represent Queen‚Äôs 36th District in the state Assembly.

He‚Äôs declared the exact same amount of ‚Äúless than $2,000‚Äù for five years in a row in filings to the state Legislative Ethics Commission.

‚ÄúMore drama from a guy who grew up with three silver spoons in his mouth,‚Äù quipped political strategist Hank Sheinkopf.

‚ÄúIf anybody believes that Mamdani is a poor person, they need to see a psychiatrist. This is a complete lie. He‚Äôs trying to sell people this nonsense that he‚Äôs this poor kid,‚Äù he told The Post.

State lawmakers are only required to report investments and retirement plans, and don‚Äôt have to disclose how much they have in regular savings or checking accounts.

They are also not required to reveal trust funds established by their relatives ‚Äî and in Mamdani‚Äôs case that could be a windfall, observers have noted.

Mamdani‚Äôs mother, Mira Nair, is an Academy Award- and Golden Globe-nominated filmmaker,¬†who has made movies for Disney and a series for Netflix, and whose productions have starred the likes of Denzel Washington.

Nair sold a posh West Chelsea 2-bedroom that she had owned for more than 10 years in 2019 for $1.45 million.¬†

His father,¬†Mahmood Mamdani, is a chaired professor of African history and colonialism at Columbia University who won multiple prizes and published more than a dozen books.

Professors in similar positions make an average of $308,000 a year, according to American Association of University Professors data.

The Harvard-educated couple still live in the stylish Ivy League and taxpayer-subsidized 3-bed, 3-bath corner apartment on Riverside Drive ‚Äî with weekly maid service ‚Äî where Mamdani grew up while he attended elite $66,000-a-year Bank Street School.

‚ÄúThis is all nonsense and an attempt to show that he‚Äôs a man of the people when he‚Äôs about as close to the people as Nelson Rockefeller was,‚Äù said Sheinkopf.

Critics pointed to Mamdani‚Äôs recently resurfaced hand-eating stunt as proof of the ‚Äútax the rich‚Äù socialist trying to sell his narrative.

‚ÄúA perpetual theatre kid who‚Äôs pretending to be ‚ÄòThird World.‚Äô It‚Äôs all so, so performative + stupid,‚Äù railed Manhattan Institute fellow Renu Mukherjee on X.

‚ÄúHe looks uncomfortable eating with his hands,‚Äù she noted.

Mamdani was a self-described ‚ÄúB-list rapper,‚Äù performing under the stage name ‚ÄúMr. Cardamom‚Äù before he went into politics.

He also sometimes went by the moniker ‚ÄúYoung Cardamom,‚Äù like in the song ‚Äú#1 spice‚Äù that was part of the soundtrack for his mother‚Äôs Disney movie.

The former rapper turned politician disclosed up to $5,000 in royalties in 2024 from his musical stint.

Mamdani‚Äôs office declined to comment.
item.author: Gabrielle Fahmy

item.title: ÂâçAOCÊîØÊåÅËÄÖÂØπÂπ¥ËΩªÁöÑMamdaniÁ≤â‰∏ùÂèëÂá∫‰∏•ÂéâË≠¶ÂëäÔºö ‚Äú‰ªñ‰ª¨Ê≠£Âú®Âá∫ÂîÆ‰∏ÄÁßç‰∏çËµ∑‰ΩúÁî®ÁöÑÂπªÊÉ≥‚Äù | Former AOC backer has stark warning for young Mamdani fans: ‚ÄòThey‚Äôre selling a fantasy that doesn‚Äôt work‚Äô
item.description:
A former AOC supporter has come out with a stark warning for young Big Apple voters in the wake of socialist Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs Democratic primary victory.

‚ÄúIf I was 25, I would‚Äôve been obsessed with Zohran,‚Äù Lucy Biggers admits in a video she posted last week on X.

‚ÄúNow I‚Äôm 35, and I‚Äôve grown up. The feel-good promises of free college, free food, free housing might sound great, but they don‚Äôt work.‚Äù

She goes on to explain her view that socialist policies make cities poorer because rich people leave, while everyone else is left stuck with higher taxes ‚Äî and little to show for it.

‚ÄúThe road to hell is paved with good intentions.‚Äù

Biggers, who works in media,¬†says she helped propel AOC from a virtual unknown to¬†political juggernaut in 2018.

‚ÄúI met AOC when she was basically a nobody. And I really thought she had something special going on, so I booked her for an interview at our studios,‚Äù Biggers told The Post.

She produced a viral video for progressive social media site Now This which Ocasio-Cortez‚Äô campaign ended up paying to promote on social media.

‚ÄúThey downloaded it, and they used it as a campaign asset . . . they used it as a digital ad,‚Äù said Biggers, who‚Äôs now social media editor at The Free Press.

AOC shockingly defeated 10-term incumbent Rep. Joe Crowley in the 2018 Democratic Primary for New York‚Äôs 14th Congressional District, before she went on to win the seat in the midterm election that November.

‚ÄúThe video got her message out. At that time, no one cared about AOC, she was not on cable news,‚Äù Biggers recalled.

Fast forward seven years, and Biggers, who now is a homeowner and a mother of two in Connecticut, is seeing things a bit differently.

She said the pandemic and the impact of government spending was a big turning point.

‚ÄúAs you grow up, you start to see the world less black and white. You can‚Äôt sell this bill of goods that promises to create a utopia in America,‚Äù said Biggers, who works in the city.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a glorification of socialism among young people. They don‚Äôt know what happened in Cuba, Venezuela, the USSR. They glamorize these countries and are indoctrinated into thinking the US is bad. It‚Äôs very naive . . . it‚Äôs embarrassing,‚Äù she said, reflecting on her own views back then.

Voter energy behind Mamdani is authentic, but the enthusiasm is entirely misplaced, Biggers said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs young people who want to make a change. And he ran a really great campaign honestly,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúBut I just think it‚Äôs selling a fantasy that ultimately doesn‚Äôt work.‚Äù

Ocasio-Cortez‚Äô and Mamdani‚Äôs offices declined to comment.
item.author: Gabrielle Fahmy

item.title: Â§öÂêçÊÄßÁäØÁΩ™ËÄÖÔºàÂåÖÊã¨‰∏ÄÂêçÂº∫Â•∏7Â≤ÅÂ•≥Â≠©ÁöÑÁäØÁΩ™ËÄÖÔºâË¢´ÂÆâÁΩÆÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ÂÑøÁ´•ÂÖ¨Âõ≠ÈôÑËøëÁöÑÂ∫áÊä§ÊâÄ | Multiple sex offenders ‚Äî including one who raped 7-year-old girl ‚Äî housed in NYC shelter feet from kids park
item.description:
The city has quietly turned a former hotel into a taxpayer-funded den for child predators and other sex offenders ‚Äî located less than 250 feet from a playground, The Post has learned.

At least five level 2 and level 3 sex offenders ‚Äî the worst of the worst, including one monster who had sex with a 7-year-old ‚Äî are living in a homeless shelter at 61 Chrystie St., 243 feet from the Hester Street Playground in Chinatown.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs so much wrong with this, I don‚Äôt even know where to begin,‚Äù said resident Brian Chin, the father of a 4-year-old boy and 9-year-old girl who he no longer allows on that playground.

‚ÄúFinding out that the city has secretly been putting child predators into an all-expenses paid hotel overlooking the children‚Äôs park, on the taxpayers dime, it verges on being almost unbelievable,‚Äù said the irate dad, a neighborhood activist who researched the hotel and discovered the city was placing sex offenders there.

‚ÄúThe sheer amount of sex offenders concentrated in that one hotel, the fact that they‚Äôre free to roam around, and that it‚Äôs literally situated directly across from the kids park and the local high school, it‚Äôs appalling.‚Äù

State law prohibits level 2 and 3 sex offenders, who are considered at medium and high risk of reoffending, from living within 1,320 feet ‚Äî or a quarter mile ‚Äî of playgrounds, schools, parks and childcare facilities.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt even know how many level 1 sex offenders are living there because they‚Äôre not listed [in the state sex-offender registry],‚Äù Chin said of the lowest level predators.

The shelter was once a boutique hotel called Hotel MB and before that a Comfort Inn. It was converted into a homeless facility in the summer of 2021, according to reports online. It is not clear when the city began moving in the sex offenders or how many of them live at the site. The Post has reached out to city officials.

The shelter is run by a Bronx-based non-profit called the Neighborhood Association for Inter-Cultural Affairs Inc. (NAICA), which has pocketed nearly $1.3 billion in city contracts the past decade, records show.

NAICA‚Äôs Chrystie Street location was part of a four-year $160.5 million contract with DHS to provide 467 beds for single adults there and at two other locations in the Bronx and Queens, according to the city Comptroller‚Äôs office.

That deal expired June 30, but DHS ironed out a one-year, $42.2 million extension, according to a legal notice on the city‚Äôs website.¬†The new contract has yet to be registered with the Comptroller‚Äôs office.

The sex offenders living there, according to the state‚Äôs Sex Offender Registry, include:

  • Darren Jackson, 63: Level-3 offender convicted in 2010 for raping a 7-year-old girl multiple times and sentenced to three years in prison.¬†¬†
  • Lemar Jackson, 57: Level 3 offender convicted in 2008 for deviate sexual intercourse for using threats and physically overpowering 12- and 9-year-old girls and sentenced to two to four years in state prison.¬†
  • Elvin Vega, 57: Level 3 offender convicted in 1998 for using a blunt object to force a female of unknown age¬†to have intercourse, and sentenced to 18 months to three years in state prison.
  • Legrand Jones, 63: Level 2 sexually violent offender convicted of sexual abuse in 2003 for overpowering a 21-year-old woman and forcing her to have sex. Sentenced to two to four years in prison. ¬†
  • Terrence Brown, 59: Level 2 offender convicted of forcible touching another person‚Äôs intimate parts in 2009 and sentenced to six months.¬†¬†

Some area activists became aware the hotel was being used as a shelter for parolees back in 2021 and raised their concerns ‚Äî but nothing changed, according to Jacky Wong, managing director of the greater Chinatown Civic Coalition.

‚ÄúBoth DHS [Department of Homeless Services] and the hotel owner had previously assured us that this parolee shelter would close in June 2022,‚Äù Wong said. ‚ÄúBut they lied. It‚Äôs still operating. This shelter, along with other nearby facilities for single men, has directly and indirectly contributed to increased crime and safety concerns in and around Sara D. Roosevelt Park.‚Äù

Murder, rape, robbery and assault are all up so far this year over last in the 5th Precinct, which encapsulates most of Chinatown.

There have been two murders in the precinct this year so far as compared to none in the same period last year, according to NYPD data. Robbery is up 29%, to 76 incidents so far this year from 59 last year. Felony assault has increased 3.9% to 106 so far this year, compared to 102 in the same span of last year. Rape is up 80% to nine so far this year compared to five in the same period of 2024, the data show.

Wong pointed to the assault and attempted rape of an 80-year-old woman in November near the corner of Grand Street and Chrystie Street.¬†

‚ÄúThere is no accountability from these shelter operators, and DHS continues to target low-income communities of color like ours for these placements,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThis is discriminatory and unacceptable.‚Äù¬†

Sex offenders aren‚Äôt supposed to be housed in shelters in residential neighborhoods, said Republican mayoral candidate Curtis Sliwa.

‚ÄúThis is part of the shelter problem,‚Äù Sliwa said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs become a cottage industry where there are contracts and then obviously, the people who get the contracts, subcontract out, all the ancillary services to friends and relatives and associates, but the one thing that they should be doing is vetting who it is that actually is in a shelter and they don‚Äôt.‚Äù

The city Department of Social Services released a statement saying that not everyone required to register in the sex offender database has residency restrictions.

‚ÄúDSS provides shelter to anyone in need in accordance with New York City‚Äôs right to shelter law while also ensuring compliance with all necessary local laws and regulations which includes being mindful of any residency restrictions and specific criteria laid out in state law,‚Äù the statement said.

The agency didn‚Äôt respond to a follow up question about why level 2 and 3 offenders were permitted to live so close to a playground.

Many people who were in the park with their children Wednesday were upset to learn of the shelter sickos.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm super pissed off, I‚Äôm talking to my husband right now on the phone and he‚Äôs extremely mad as well,‚Äù said a 29-year-old mom who takes her two kids to the playground at least twice a week. ‚ÄúThey shouldn‚Äôt be anywhere near the park.‚Äù¬†

Brooklyn choreographer John Quinones, a 42-year-old grandfather, was ‚Äúhorrified.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm the type of person that would want to take actions into my own hands and probably get in trouble,‚Äù he said.

Resident Daiya Williams was adamant that the city should have at least notified parents.

‚ÄúGiven it‚Äôs New York City anything can happen, and I don‚Äôt want to take the chance,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not safe.‚Äù

Chin plans to keep calling attention to the problem.

‚ÄúPlacing violent child sex predators across from our children‚Äôs park, the city and the officials who approved this need to be held accountable,‚Äù the dad said. ‚ÄúI think I can confidently speak for all of us when I say that enough is enough.‚Äù¬†

NAICA did not return requests for comment.

Additional reporting by Samantha Olander
item.author: Georgett Roberts, Rich Calder, Tina Moore

item.title: Â∑•‰ºöÈ¢ÜÂØº‰∫∫È¢ÑÊµãÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúZohran MamdaniËé∑ËÉúÔºåÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇË≠¶ÂØüÂ∞Ü‰ª•ÂéÜÂè≤ÊÄßÁöÑÊï∞Â≠óÈÄÉÁ¶ªËøô‰ªΩÂ∑•‰Ωú | NYC cops would flee the job in historic numbers if Zohran Mamdani wins, union leaders predict
item.description:
Police officers are retiring in historic numbers ‚Äî and the exodus will only accelerate if anti-cop Democratic Mayoral nominee Zohran Mamdani is elected, union officials warned this week.

As of Monday, 1,555 NYPD officers put in their papers ‚Äî 48% more than the 1,049 who retired last year, and 65% more than a decade ago, when just 941 turned in their shields, according to NYPD data provided to The Post by the Police Benevolent Association.

Union leaders weren‚Äôt aware of any time in history that retirements for the first six months of year were as high, and worry about the disastrous affect the lefty Mamdani could have on NYPD recruitment and retention.

‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt afford to have a mayor who ignores the problem or tries to take us backward,‚Äù said PBA President Patrick Hendry. ‚ÄúWe need a mayor who will speak up for police officers, and treat us and pay us like the professionals we are.‚Äù

The PBA hasn‚Äôt endorsed a mayoral candidate in this year‚Äôs race.

What the self-described Democratic socialist‚Äôs policies could mean to public safety and New York‚Äôs Finest is pushing some cops to leave, according to a Queens cop who is planning to put his papers in this month.

‚ÄúThe Democratic candidate who won is very anti-cop,‚Äù said the officer, who has more than 20 years on the job. ‚ÄúHe has an extremist attitude and it‚Äôs going to scare other cops and they will go out the door.‚Äù

The cop has been particularly incensed over ‚Äúblanket statements‚Äù Mandami has made about cops, including advocating for defunding the NYPD, a stance he later reversed during a debate in June.

Mandami has labeled the NYPD ‚Äúwicked and corrupt‚Äù on X, and called for the department to be dismantled.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve never met us but you‚Äôre saying that we‚Äôre biased?‚Äù said the cop. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs offensive to everyone in law enforcement. Meanwhile, he doesn‚Äôt talk to cops.‚Äù

The officer ‚Äî who took the test to join the NYPD a year after the Sept. 11, 2001 terror attacks on the World Trade Center ‚Äî said Mamdani‚Äôs June 24 Democratic primary win cinched his decision to leave.

‚ÄúHim winning the primary definitely made me 100% sure that this is the right decision,‚Äù said the cop, who asked to remain anonymous because he wasn‚Äôt authorized to speak to the media.

A new wave of anti-cop sentiment ‚Äî similar to what the officer heard during the George Floyd protests of 2020 ‚Äî also helped make up his mind, he said.

‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt get any support from politicians,‚Äù he said of the chaotic demonstrations which plagued the city and the nation in the months after Floyd‚Äôs death.

‚ÄúWe need a leader that‚Äôs not going to come with an anti-police attitude,‚Äù he said, pointing to Mayor Adams, a former police captain, a Democrat who will run on the Independent ticket. ‚ÄúThe current administration has been very supportive of cops.‚Äù

The NYPD‚Äôs largest incoming classes were in 2005, when about 3,600 police officers joined the Force, so more cops are hitting the 20-year mark and are eligible to retire and take their pensions, NYPD spokeswoman Delaney Kempner pointed out.

‚ÄúIt is no secret that we are facing a staffing crisis across the NYPD, and hiring and recruitment efforts remain a priority,‚Äù the department said in a statement.

The NYPD has reduced the number of college credits required to become a cop to attract more candidates.

Rules that make it beneficial for cops to retire when they‚Äôve had their best year financially are also sparking the 2025 exodus.

That‚Äôs where many police officers found themselves after taking advantage of overtime as NYPD Commissioner Jessica Tisch deployed hundreds of cops underground to fight subway crime and improve public perception.¬†

Every week, Post columnist Miranda Devine sits down for exclusive and candid conversations with the most influential disruptors in Washington. Subscribe here!

City Hall and Albany have been working to try to repair the staffing crisis with increased recruitment and a series of new Academy classes that have brought on about 1,700 new cops this year, the PBA pointed out.

‚ÄúNearly every leader now at 1 Police Plaza, City Hall and Albany agrees that this crisis is serious,‚Äù Hendry said.

The retirements aren‚Äôt limited to the PBA.

The Detectives Endowment Association is also seeing an uptick this year, DEA President Scott Munro said.

So far, 606 gumshoes have retired as of July 1, according to the DEA‚Äôs data. Last year, there were 455 retirements all year.

The NYPD has seen a 33% drop in the number of detectives in its ranks, to 4,716 today from a high of¬†7,000 in 2001, Munro said.¬†

‚ÄúIf Mamdani does get elected there‚Äôs going to be mass retirement,‚Äù Munro predicted. ‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt believe in law enforcement.‚Äù

Lieutenants Benevolent Association President Lou Turco said some of Mamdani‚Äôs comments about police officers in the past concerned him.

‚ÄúRight now, we have a recruitment retention problem,‚Äù Turco said. ‚ÄúBut if he gets in, more guys with over 20 [years] are going to say ‚ÄòWhat am I doing this for?‚Äô‚Äù
item.author: Tina Moore

item.title: ‰∏§Âà∞Êé¢ÊààÔºöËàûËÄÖÂ£∞Áß∞‰ª£Ë°®Ë¢´Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ÂøÉÁêÜÂåªÁîüÊØÅ‰∫ÜÔºå‰ªñÊåáË¥£‰ªñÂä†‰∫ÜÈ•ÆÊñô | Two to tango: Dancer claims rep ruined by NYC shrink who accused him of spiking drink
item.description:
It takes two to tango but apparently just one after-party to ruin a reputation.

A suburban Seattle man and tango enthusiast claims a gin-soaked late-night gathering at a California Airbnb with his fellow dance lovers left him shunned when one later accused him of spiking the drinks.

Eduard Koller showed up at a small gathering after the March 2023 Southern California Tango Festival with tequila and ‚Äúa gin-based cocktail‚Äù in hand, according to a lawsuit.

The party broke up without incident and Koller, 55, took an Uber back to his hotel along with four of his party guests.

But a year later, Koller claims he was barred from a tango marathon in Massachusetts because the co-organizer believed he‚Äôd been ‚Äúinappropriate,‚Äù he said in Manhattan Supreme Court papers.

James Oh allegedly told the Redmond, Wash. man only that he‚Äôd received ‚Äúmultiple credible claims of inappropriate and harmful behaviors by you. And I‚Äôm not comfortable letting you be part of any event I‚Äôm organizing or co-organizing,‚Äù according to the litigation.

Koller later learned Upper East Side psychologist Tehela Nimroody had accused him of tampering with her beverage during the California after-party, he said in legal papers.

The pair were not alone during the party in question and ‚Äúdid not share any other type of relationship or interactions‚Äù aside from meeting at three tango events between 2022 and 2024, Koller claimed.

Nimroody allegedly ignored a Facebook message Koller sent seeking to clarify her claim, he noted.

Koller is seeking unspecified damages and wants a court order barring Oh and Nimroody from posting any ‚Äúdefamatory and injurious content‚Äù about him.

Oh declined comment on the litigation. Nimroody did not respond to messages.
item.author: Kathianne Boniello

item.title: ÈÄÉÁ®é‰ºóËÆÆÂëòÊü•Â∞îÊñØ¬∑ÂÖ∞Ê†ºÂ∞îÔºà Charles Rangel ÔºâÁïô‰∏ã‰∫Ü‰∏ÄÁ¨î‰∏çÂ§ßÁöÑÈÅó‰∫ß‚ÄîÈÄÄ‰ºëÂêéÁöÑÂáÄËµÑ‰∫ßËøú‰Ωé‰∫é170‰∏áÁæéÂÖÉÔºöËÆ∞ÂΩï | Tax-dodging Rep. Charles Rangel left behind modest estate ‚Äî much less than $1.7M net worth upon retirement: records
item.description:
Harlem Rep. Charles Rangel ‚Äî infamously known for pocketing rental income from his Caribbean cottage without disclosing it ‚Äî has apparently left behind a modest estate, court records show.

Rangel, who died May 26 at age 94, had assets worth only $300,000, according to Manhattan Surrogate Court filings.

That is far less than his net worth of more than $1.7 million upon his retirement from Congress in 2017, as reported by the watchdog group Open Secrets.

The current assets of the once-powerful chair of the House‚Äôs Ways and Means Committee were not detailed in court filings.

His daughter, Alicia Rangel-Haughton, was named executor of the Democrat‚Äôs estate.

The late representative‚Äôs property is to be placed in the Charles Bernard Rangel Revocable Trust, the assets of which were not disclosed in a will signed March 31, just nine weeks before his death at Harlem Hospital.

Rangels‚Äô financial misbehavior and other ethical questions dogged him throughout his decades-long career, long before The Post outed his business dealings in Punta Cana, Dominican Republic.

He was criticized right from the start of his career when, in the 1960s, he took a low-interest loan from a¬†New York City program meant to help the poor and used it to renovate his family‚Äôs Central Harlem home, turning the property into rental apartments ‚Äî one of which he used for himself.

Decades later, Rangel was caught using four rent-stabilized apartments in Lenox Terrace for himself, including one he used as a campaign office.

He parked his vintage Mercedes for free in a House of Representatives garage; was questioned for his participation in junkets to the Caribbean sponsored by corporations and lobbyists in violation of House rules, and eventually copped to omitting as much as $780,000 in assets from financial disclosures he filed in the 2000s.

He was also slammed for using Congressional stationery to solicit donations for the Charles B. Rangel Center for Public Service at the City College of New York, a move which broke House ethics rules.

A week after The Post‚Äôs 2008 expos√© revealed Rangel‚Äôs ownership of the three-bedroom, three-bath casita No. 412¬†at a beachfront resort in Punta Cana ‚Äî which he rented out for between $500 and $1,100 a night ‚Äî he confessed he‚Äôd failed to disclose rental income from the property.

Rangel failed to declare $75,000 in income from the sun-drenched property, he eventually admitted. He unloaded the villa in 2010 and made a handsome profit.

In December 2010, Rangel‚Äôs financial misdeeds earned him a censure from his Congressional colleagues. He retired from Congress in 2017.
item.author: Kathianne Boniello

item.title: ÂèóÁôåÁóáÂΩ±ÂìçÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÊµ∑ÂÜõÈôÜÊàòÈòüÂëòÂú®Êö¥Èú≤‰∫éLejeuneËê•ÁöÑÊúâÊØíÊ∞¥ÂêéÁ≠âÂæÖÊî∂Ê¨æÊó∂Ê≠ª‰∫° | Cancer-stricken NYC Marine dies while waiting for payout after exposure to Camp Lejeune‚Äôs toxic water
item.description:
A retired Marine reservist from Harlem who spent months fighting for recognition alongside thousands of other veterans allegedly poisoned by toxic water while serving at Camp Lejeune has died, his family said.

Richard Corley suffered esophageal cancer and was battling a tumor next to his pancreas when he entered hospice care several months ago, two of his three kids told The Post. He was 66.

His June 23 death at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx came 16 months after he filed a claim with the federal government, seeking compensation for the illness he believed was caused by the water at the famed US Marine base in Jacksonville, NC.

‚ÄúIf he‚Äôd had some resources, there were some things on his bucket list he never got a chance to complete,‚Äù said son Royce Corley, recalling how he‚Äôd gotten his passport and wanted to travel to visit family in the Caribbean. ‚ÄúHe never got a chance.‚Äô

His case ‚Äúnow goes to a wrongful death claim, and because of that he‚Äôs entitled to more compensation but it‚Äôs bittersweet,‚Äù the son added. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather have my father be alive to see that justice be done.‚Äù

Corley, who first served at Camp Lejeune in 1982, attained the rank of gunnery sergeant and worked in real estate until he became ill.

His final days were spent in ‚Äúexcruciating pain,‚Äù but Corley ‚Äúwas still fighting. He was still tough,‚Äù his son said.

Sick and dying veterans such as Corley thought help finally arrived in August 2022, when Congress passed the Camp Lejeune Justice Act, which allowed those diagnosed with one of 15 different illnesses¬†who served at the base from 1953 to 1987 to file a claim with the US Navy, and to sue if the claim is rejected or ignored.

As¬†many as a million military members, their families and civilian staffers¬†are believed to have been exposed to contaminated water for decades.

To date, more than 500,000 claims have been filed with the US Department of Justice ‚Äî but so far less than 500 have been settled, according to Corley‚Äôs lawyers, who noted hundreds of veterans have died while waiting for compensation.

‚ÄúThis shouldn‚Äôt be just thrown to the wayside because he is deceased,‚Äù said Corley‚Äôs daughter Chantel. ‚ÄúThey can rectify it properly and lay this to rest as it needs to be. There are other people who are effected by this.‚Äù
item.author: Kathianne Boniello

item.title: ÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÂØπÂØå‰∫∫ÂæÅÁ®éÁöÑZohran MamdaniÁöÑÂ••Â∞îÂ∑¥Â∞ºÂêåÂøóÂπ∂Ê≤°ÊúâÂõ†‰∏∫Áé∞ÈáëËÄåÂèóÂà∞‰º§ÂÆ≥ | Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs Albany comrades who want to tax the rich are not hurting for cash
item.description:
Albany‚Äôs self-proclaimed socialists and progressives aren‚Äôt hurting for cash.

State Sen. Liz Krueger, who pushed for so-called ‚Äúrent control for the rich‚Äù under the pretense of helping the middle class, has close to an eye-watering $24 million in investments, according to newly released 2024 financial disclosures.

It‚Äôs unlikely that fortune is based solely off the progressive pol‚Äôs $142,000 a year salary as a state senator ‚Äî an office she‚Äôs held since 2002.

Krueger‚Äôs father, Harvey, was CEO of an investment bank that merged with Lehman Brothers, where he became vice chairman.

The wealth of the Ridgewood native ‚Äî who said New York should ditch the land of the free and join the Great White North after President Trump‚Äôs election ‚Äî could be even bigger, as state lawmakers don‚Äôt have to disclose money held in trusts set up by relatives.

Krueger, 67, who lives on Manhattan‚Äôs Upper East Side with her retired CUNY professor husband, owns an assortment of stocks and bonds, including close to $8 million worth of Apple, the disclosures revealed.

Another progressive lawmaker, Lt. Gov. Antonio Delgado, holds close to $1.1 million in bank accounts.

His wife, Lacey Schwartz Delgado, is an Emmy-nominated filmmaker who sits on several film boards, according to the filings.

The lieutenant governor, nicknamed ‚ÄúNo Show Delgado‚Äù because he‚Äôs missed hundreds of days of work as Gov. Hochul‚Äôs $220,000-a-year deputy, is vying for Hochul‚Äôs gig.

Then there‚Äôs socialist State Sen. Jabari Brisport, one of mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs comrades in Albany who once slammed capitalism with AOC.

He sold his holdings in cryptocurrency Ethereum last year to put up to $250,000 in a ‚ÄúUS Vegan Climate ETF.‚Äù

Other disclosures revealed:

  • Assemblymember Phara Souffrant Forrest, 36, somehow juggles representing Brooklyn with a $50,000 side gig as a registered nurse. She worked at the Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx last year, according to her disclosure.
  • Emily Gallagher, the anti-car Brooklyn assemblywoman who racked up dozens of traffic tickets, disclosed a new gig for her hubby. After brief stints at a Greenpoint arts supply store and a wine shop, Andrew Ward Lundwall now works at a Williamsburg weed shop doing inventory.
item.author: Gabrielle Fahmy

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â§©‰∏ªÊïôÁªÑÁªá‰∏∫‰ªéÊ¢ØÂ≠ê‰∏äÊëî‰∏ãÊù•ÁöÑÁª¥‰øÆÂ∑•‰∫∫Âà∂ÈÄ†‰∫ÜÁîüÊ¥ªÂú∞Áã±ÔºöËØâËÆº | NYC Catholic organization made life hell for maintenance worker who fell from ladder: lawsuit
item.description:
His holiness would not approve.

Life was hell for an Irish Catholic maintenance worker for the Sisters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul in the Bronx ‚Äî where his Protestant boss allegedly bashed him as a ‚ÄúCatholic f‚Äìk‚Äù and a ‚Äúdumb Irish bastard.‚Äù

And the nuns were mean too ‚Äì complaining about Michael Carr‚Äôs limp after he fell from a ladder, he said in court papers.

Carr, 57, treasured his work fixing up the Riverdale property, until director Kevin Van Tassell sent a slew of hate his way ‚Äî even calling him the N-word, he claimed in a Manhattan Federal Court lawsuit.

Van Tassell repeatedly texted him the vile slur, as well as calling him a ‚Äúmick,‚Äù ‚ÄúCatholic f‚Äìk,‚Äù ‚ÄúIrish f‚Äìk‚Äù he claimed in court papers.

The lifelong Catholic, who grew up attending St. Margaret of Cortona in the Bronx and proudly showed his mother around his new job after he was hired in 2017, said the abuse was intolerable.

‚ÄúIt got to the point where I couldn‚Äôt take it any more,‚Äù an emotional Carr told The Post. ‚ÄúI was putting up with¬†it. . . . He would call nuns old c‚Äìts and I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄòOMG.‚Äô He‚Äôd say, ‚ÄòHey ya big dumb Irish f‚Äìk‚Äô or ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs up ya mick.‚Äô It could go on and on.‚Äù¬†

When he complained, Carr said he was ignored for weeks before supervisors scheduled a mediation between him and Van Tassell, who failed to show up at the meeting with human resources, according to the litigation.

‚ÄúDo you know what it‚Äôs like when no one will listen to you, no matter what direction you turn?‚Äù Carr said. ‚ÄúNobody wanted to know. They all knew, but they didn‚Äôt want to know.‚Äù

After being lauded on the job for years for his work ethic, Carr claims he was seriously hurt in October 2023 when he fell from a ladder while investigating an awning in need of repair, breaking his tibia and fibula and leaving him in need of several surgeries.

When he was finally able to return to work, the reception he got was far less than charitable, claimed Carr, who said he walked with a limp and was slower than in the past.

‚ÄúThe sisters are complaining,‚Äù Carr claimed he was told.

‚ÄúI tried my hardest to make this work. My foot is destroyed. I have to get more surgery. The second day in I was told I was working too slow, and ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre limping,‚Äô ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre taking too long,'‚Äù he said.

He was then sent home and weeks later, received a letter firing him, said Carr, who is seeking unspecified damages for wrongful termination.

‚ÄúHopefully this organization will take a hard look at itself,‚Äù said Carr‚Äôs attorney, Joseph Jeziorkowski. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the organization‚Äôs responsibility to take action when an employee is going through something like this.‚Äù

Van Tassell refused comment. The Sisters of Charity declined comment.
item.author: Kathianne Boniello

item.title: ÂºÄÊãìÊÄßÁöÑÂìàËé±ÂßÜÁéØÁêÉÊóÖË°åËÄÖLynette WoodardËØ¥ÔºåÂ•π‰ªéÊú™ËßÅËøá‰ª•Â•πÁöÑÂêç‰πâÂá∫ÂîÆÁöÑÂïÜÂìÅ‰∏≠ÁöÑ‰∏ÄÂàÜÈí± | Trailblazing Harlem Globetrotter Lynette Woodard says she never saw a penny from merch sold in her name
item.description:
A gold medal-winning Olympian and historic Harlem Globetrotter claims she‚Äôs been dunked on by an NYC business that sold pricey hoodies and sweatsuits in her name ‚Äî and cut her out of the profits.

Hall of Famer Lynette Woodard, who became the first woman to play for the famed Globetrotters in 1985, said in a lawsuit that no one got her permission to slap her name on $150 hoodies and $100 sweats peddled by a company called Undrcrwn.

The Globetrotters and the company ‚Äúnever sought [Woodard‚Äôs] consent because they knew [she] would not give it for free,‚Äù she said in the Manhattan Federal Court lawsuit.

The 65-year-old, 6-foot-tall guard, who captained the gold medal-winning US Olympic team in 1984 in Los Angeles, said the offending products were sold between 2021 and 2024 and are still available on the secondary market.

The two-time All-American at the University of Kansas who is also the all-time leading scorer in women‚Äôs college basketball is seeking unspecified damages.

Woodard also played in the inaugural season of the WNBA for the Cleveland Rockers.

Undrcrwn and the Globetrotters did not respond to messages seeking comment.
item.author: Kathianne Boniello

item.title: Áôæ‰∏áÂØåÁøÅHochulsÊé•ÂèóÂ§ßËßÑÊ®°ÂáèËñ™ÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫‰∏àÂ§´ÊîæÂºÉ‰∫ÜÊúâ‰∫âËÆÆÁöÑÊ∏∏ÊàèÊºîÂá∫ | Millionaire Hochuls take massive pay cut as hubby ditches controversial gaming gig
item.description:
New York Gov. Hochul and hubby have between $2.2 million and $4.3 million in the bank‚Äì less than they‚Äôve declared in the past, newly released state financial disclosures show.

William Hochul Jr. took a job defending white-collar criminals for Manhattan law firm Davis Polk in January 2024, making between $850,000 and $950,000 last year, according to the 2024 filings, which do not include exact income figures but a range.

It‚Äôs a significant pay cut from the $1.45 to $1.55 million he made the year before as counsel for gaming giant Delaware North, a gig he left in August 2023 amid conflicts-of-interest controversies.

His company was lobbying his wife‚Äôs office over lucrative contracts and sports betting. Reports found Hochul‚Äôs administration took steps in several disputes involving upstate gambling rights that were in line with the interests of her hubby‚Äôs multibillion-dollar firm.

The first gentleman still received deferred compensation of close to $100,000 from Delaware North in 2024, filings show.

Bill Hochul‚Äôs reduced income wasn‚Äôt the only hit to the couple‚Äôs pocketbook ‚Äî the cash in their accounts shrank from a range between $2.9 and $5.6 million in 2023.

Filings show they sold some investments ‚Äì but it‚Äôs not clear where the money went. The Post has reached out to Gov. Hochul‚Äôs office.

The couple held as many as 180 different stocks and financial assets in 2023 ‚Äî more than She-Wolf of Wall Street Nancy Pelosi.

By 2024, that number dipped slightly to 120.

The Hochuls didn‚Äôt report any new real estate purchases, and no property ‚Äî despite being known to own at least one home, a waterfront condo in Buffalo worth upwards of $800,000.

State lawmakers aren‚Äôt required to disclose primary residences. And though she lives in the governor‚Äôs mansion in Albany, the Buffalo house is likely still listed as Hochul‚Äôs primary residence.
item.author: Gabrielle Fahmy

item.title: Ë¢´Áß∞‰∏∫‚ÄúÂ§ßËÑö‚ÄùÁöÑÂøÉÁêÜÂåªÁîüÂõ†Áå•‰∫µË¢´ÊãòÁïôÁöÑÈùíÂ∞ëÂπ¥ËÄåË¢´ÊçïÂêéËÆ§ÁΩ™ | Shrink known as ‚ÄòBig Foot‚Äô pleads guilty after her arrest for molesting detained teens
item.description:
A shrink known as ‚ÄúBig Foot‚Äù who was accused of raping and sexually abusing at least five victims at an upstate New York juvenile detention center has pleaded guilty to a criminal charge in the case.

Maya Hayes, 47, faces up to 2 1/2 years in state prison after pleading guilty June 25 to one felony count of criminal sexual act under a plea deal with Columbia County prosecutors.

Hayes could also be slapped with 10 years of post-release supervision and forced to register as a sex offender for a minimum of 20 years when she is sentenced in September, the Columbia District Attorney‚Äôs Office said.

Hayes faces several lawsuits from nearly half a dozen young men who claimed she plied them with phone privileges, hair products and food while regularly fondling them and forcing them to squeeze her breasts, according to court papers.

The alleged abuse unfolded at Brookwood Youth Facility near Albany, where one of the accusers was as young as 15.

The counselor allegedly wanted to have oral sex with her young charges ‚Äúbecause she was sexually frustrated at home,‚Äù one alleged victim said Hayes told him, according to a Manhattan Federal Court lawsuit filed by three accusers.

He added Hayes claimed ‚Äúit was her fantasy and it gave her a rush to give residents ‚Äòblow jobs.‚Äô‚Äù

She once lifted her shirt to show off her breasts while asking another boy, who was then 16, ‚ÄúDo you like big boobs?‚Äù he alleged in the legal filing.

In yet another episode of alleged abuse, Hayes was accused of asking a victim to fondle her and then complained he was ‚Äúnot squeezing her breasts hard enough,‚Äù he said in the litigation.

‚ÄúDr. Hayes‚Äô guilty plea is the first step in holding her ‚Äî and the staff at Brookwood Secure Center ‚Äìaccountable for the sexual abuse and emotional trauma our clients endured,‚Äù lawyer Evan Brustein said.

Brookwood is a¬†secure facility for those under 21. Staff knew about the abuse and allegedly joked with victims about Hayes, referring to her as ‚ÄúBig Foot.‚Äù

New York State Police¬†arrested Hayes in April¬†on 65 counts of criminal sexual act and rape.

Hayes, who could not immediately be reached for comment, denied ‚Äúall allegations‚Äù in court papers responding to one of the lawsuits.
item.author: Kathianne Boniello
